content.description: An easy slab problem that goes straight up the middle of the face. Name?
Variety of boulder problems on Sunshine’s backside.
content.location: Face the “CHRIST DIED” carving and turn 180 degrees. About 20’ in front of you is the Sunshine Boulder. The Sunshine routes are on the slab on the far side of the boulder. The boulder problems facing you are considered Sunshine’s Backside.

content.description: Three common variations: Left Sunshine goes at about 5.9, Center variation 5.10b,  Right variation 5.6 or easier.
content.protection: A cool head and a pad.    A TR can be set up by climbing the easiest route to the top on Sunshine’s Backside, and tying to the live tree that has fallen over the top of the cliff.
content.location: Face the “CHRIST DIED” carving and turn 180 degrees. About 20’ in front of you is the Sunshine Boulder. The Sunshine routes are on the slab on the far side of the boulder. (The boulder problems facing you are considered Sunshine’s Backside.)

content.description: This is the longest trad route we have found at Whipps.  Start on an overhanging, usually wet, crack on the main corner left of Christ Died.  Once through the overhang, delicately traverse about 10' to the right then up a fun 5.6/5.7 hand crack to top out.  This route is pretty fun, and when combined in a day with leading the Hinckley Crack and Christ Died Crack makes a good day of cragging for a trad leader.  Note: we haven't been able to dig up any FA info other than ours, please let us know if you have been leading this route for years!
content.protection: Full set of cams from 0.75 to 3.  Beware the first 20' as the crack is slippery when wet (usually wet) and may spit out cams!
content.location: See photos.  This is the main corner left of Christ Died when facing the main Christ Died Crack.  From Christ Died walk slightly down the hill past the downed tree to the corner where the entire wall turns direction.  You should see an overhanging 15-20' section of cracks then 10' right up higher another 15-20' of larger hand crack to the top.

content.description: Named because the series of pockets towards the top of the wall looked like a shooting star. Climb face to top.
content.protection:
TR. Anchors.

Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: Face just around the corner from Christ Died Wall.

content.description: Crimpy route between Christ Died Crack and He Had a Lot to Say. No idea if it has been climbed before - just came up with a challenging variation on the slab.All cracks and sides of cracks are off!Start low on pockets and underclings, then move up and right onto the sharp crimps of the slab. Skip the jugs and pull onto the overhanging section. Move straight up through pockets, slopers, and sloping crimps to eventually reach the final jug (the only jug you should be using!). Top out using the two nubs near/above the bolts (optional).

Boulder problem that starts in the low pockets of "O" wall and traverses right to a large sloping pocket. Using an undercling pocket continue straight up through small crimps and pockets to the break.
content.location: Between "O" wall and the Nut Cracker.

content.description: Up top there are two pockets that if you use your imagination, looks like owls eyes. One move wonder.
Another Hinkley Classic. Three variations .. all have the same start. Once you move out of the pockets either go left, straight up on finger locks and mono’s, or right.
content.protection: TR / long slings needed   Pad + cool head.
content.location: Find the carving in the rock “CHRIST DIED”. Follow the wall left to an inside corner, then left several more feet to a large maple tree. About 8’ left of the tree is the start for O Wall.

content.description: Follow crack to top
content.location: Just right of Christ Died Arete.

climbs.name: He Had a Lot to Say

content.description:
Chicken wing or jam whatever you’ve got in order to get off the ground and into the offwidth. This is the crux. Cheat by using feet outside of the crack.

Shimmy your way to the top of the detached piece, where you can exit the crack and transition to the face. Pockets take you up and along the right-trending zag to the top. 

 A traverse left after the finish may be necessary to avoid swinging into a tree if you’ve used an anchor overhead of Nut Cracker.
content.protection: Traditional anchors can be made at the top using surrounding trees. Long webbing or static line is useful here.
content.location: Locate the offwidth perhaps 10 feet right of Christ Died Crack.

content.description: Named because of the large Beech Tree that was growing right behind the crack. It could be a challenge to climb on a windy day,with the tree swaying back and forth pushing the climber into the crack. The tree is now gone. Unfortunately the crack is almostalways dirty.
content.protection:
Gear / TR. Anchors.

Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: To the right of O Wall and 5’ right of the maple tree.

content.description: Start with a pinch down and left. Climb up and right as you navigate through pockets and pinches. Slopes and jugs await as you top out.
content.protection: Multiple pads and spotters will keep you off of a rocky landing
content.location: Walk counter clockwise around the backside of Sunshine Boulder. Good Morning Sunshine is on the right side.

climbs.name: Christ! Meet in The Middle Way

content.description: Finger lay back with foot schmear, leads straight up the slab like midline to a nice ledge for traverse to anchors.
content.protection: Fixed anchors now in place. Please remember to bring your own gear!
content.location: The middle crack between Christ Died Crack and He Had a Lot to Say

content.description: Short crack to small overhang.
content.location: 3’ left of carving “CHRIST DIED FOR OUR SINS”

content.description: Short but fun. Climb the face with right hand using arete.
content.location: Right of Christ Died. Locate large tulip tree. Climb arete.

content.description: Straight up face, crack is off.
content.location: Locate “CHRIST DIED FOR OUR SINS” carved in the rock.

content.description: Traverse left from the crack keeping feet *above* the obvious line ~2-3 feet from the ground.  Crux is about half way (10 feet) from start. No idea if this had been attempted before (though imagine it has). We (Johnny Arnold and I) decided to throw down a little challenge while climbing the Christ Died Crack by adding in a long traverse. If bouldering, Route would end at He Had a Lot to Say; if using as an add-on to Christ Died Crack (or HHALTS or C!MITMW) beware of the LONG pendulum from being roped into the crack anchors (including the potential for plowing into your belayer, the tree, decking on the boulder right below HHALTS, or if your lucky to peel off further along, the long swing (hopefully) between the tree and wall. Would give this a “PG13” add-on if using as an addition to the crack.
content.protection: Pads if bouldering; TR to Christ Died Crack if adding as a start traverse
content.location: Start at the dihedral crack to the left of Christ Died.

content.description: Have no fear, the holds will appear, unless they don’t.
content.protection:
TR. Anchors.

Do not attempt to set up a Top Rope on the permanent anchors without first being attached to a secure tree or other suitable anchor.
content.location: To the right of Short Crack. Climb the face between the maple tree and the corner.

content.description: Nice area with a good concentration of short but quality climbs. The Christ Died wall gets its name from the carving in the rock    “CHRIST DIED FOR OUR SINS”.    The large slabby boulder about 20’ opposite the carving is Sunshine Boulder.   The Blade Boulder is located about 40’ downhill from Sunshine Boulder.   Walking about 50’ to the right (while facing the Blade Boulder) will take you to Bubbles Boulder.
